text: [Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
hi I'm Calvin a cloud support engineer
here at the AWS office in Sydney Today
I'm going to show you why you can't
increase the duration of an AWS identity
and access management role chaining
session beyond 1 hour Let's get
started When you use the AWS command
line interface or AWS API to assume an
AM role through temporary credentials
this is known as RO chaining With RO
chaining your RO session is limited to a
maximum duration of 1 hour or 3600
seconds Let's dive into an example In
AWS CLI I'm currently using the
credentials of an IM user as seen from
the output of the AWS STS get caller
identity
command If I try to assume a role with
the assume RO API then I can specify the
duration of the RO session with the
duration seconds parameter of up to 12
hours or
43,200 seconds depending on the maximum
session duration setting of the RO
However if I assumed a role and used its
temporary credentials to assume another
role then I'm role chaining To
demonstrate this we can see from the
output of the command AWS STS get caller
identity that I'm currently using the
temporary credentials of an IM role
Assuming a role and providing a duration
seconds parameter value greater than 1
hour the operation fails and I get this
error
So in summary when you chain roles from
the AWS CLI or AWS API you can't
increase the session duration beyond 1
hour Some points to note about RO
chaining include assign additional
permissions to the original RO to avoid
RO chaining into another role in the
same account Rochaining isn't supported
in the AWS management console And now
you know why you can't increase the
duration of a IM role chaining session
beyond 1
hour Thanks for watching and happy cloud
computing from all of us here at AWS
[Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
